text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here
internets busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new Mogwai LP
rave tapes these guys are a famed
instrumental rock band this is their
eighth studio full-length LP an album
that I was anticipating even though I
forgot to put it on my anticipated
albums of 2014 list but I was
anticipating this LP because I did enjoy
the band's last full-length LP so much
hardcore will never die but you will
Mogwai his music for the most part has
always been herded into the post rock
genre a mostly instrumental brand very
dramatic rock music they are also
considered to be one of the originators
of the genre however the band never
really felt the need to stick to the
confines the borders of this genre that
were sort of set in stone after they put
out such defining albums like young team
and happy songs were happy people and
come on die young the band's drive to
experiment has always kept their next
album interesting but I haven't always
been in love with every release that
Mogwai has put out and recently what
seems to be the direction of Mogwai
sound as they've been stepping away from
some of the drawn-out builds and really
heavy loud crescendos that they're most
known for simplifying their tracks
making them a lot more direct
straightforward and to the point like on
the 2008 LP the hawk is howling however
I don't really think Mogwai succeeded in
this direction until they came out with
hardcore will never die however this
particular LP also saw the band bringing
another change into the fold as well and
that is electronics and since things
that are definitely not strangers and
MOG wise music but the emphasis on these
things felt so much larger on this LP
especially with some of the tracks on
here that felt almost crapped rock
influenced and to me rave tapes is just
another part of this ongoing transition
and even though Mogwai is still
definitely making rock music the
synthesizers seem to be what really
gives this album direction especially on
the first few tracks here even though
there are some very prominent since in
the mix on a lot of these songs though I
wouldn't really say that Mogwai is
coming from a different place
compositionally on this record they're
still at this point in their career
where they are writing these rock tunes
that they are too loud to be ambient
they're too
allowed to just be background music
however they move it's such a slow
glacial pace I would never call them
exciting or explosive the music here are
slow it's it's repetitive and maybe that
is going to cause some people to tune
out understandably but I also think
these tracks in a way are hypnotic they
are seductive plus I do think these
songs have a strong sense of emotion too
I can really feel moods coming from
these tracks that are beautiful
epic uplifting or even bleak and dismal
and depressing and even though I do feel
these moods coming from these tracks
they can be a little ambiguous to some
of these songs feeling like a mix of all
of these feelings all these emotions
just brought together into these very
very patient songs that to me are just
like this very aggressive tranquility
like the opening track on here heard
about you last night
a song that has these delayed chime
synthesizers that ring out really
beautifully in these gently wailing
guitars soaring over some very slowly
moving bass and drum grooves it's
legitimately relaxing music
however it's not terribly memorable and
I think the obvious reaction to this
song and a lot of songs on here is well
why don't they play faster why isn't the
play more lively why isn't it louder why
isn't it just more and while I do feel
that way to an extent I also don't want
Mogwai to abandon their very clear
relaxation mission because I do think
they're on the cusp of making music that
is very gentle on the ears is very soft
but is also engaging and incredibly
enjoyable even though every song on here
isn't exactly Wow
I do think that Mogwai does bring some
variety to the table the song SIMON
ferocious is one of the noisier tracks
on here faintly psychedelic with its
wailing wall of guitars and the song
features these really rough saw tone
bass sense as well that sort of buzz and
gurgle their way through the track and
the closing track on here which has
vocoder vocals on it also something
Mogwai has done before but this track
does feel a little refreshing in that it
is the most electronic song in this
entire album some of the drums in the
background feel like they're
synthetically generated
and the since really take the wheel on
this track to songs like this ride the
border between blissful and mundane so
hard that it actually blurs the lines
between the both of them a little bit
and even though I really admire what
songs like this are aiming for the
tracks on here that are going for
something completely different are the
ones that I admire and remember the most
like the song reamer dird which feels
like something that could come out of a
progressive synthesizer rock album
soundtrack for some sort of sci-fi film
from decades ago if you're into the
music of goblin or zombie I could
definitely see you enjoying this track
and then there's the song MasterCard
which has these really sharp shrill
rhythm guitars that grab my attention
right from the start it's got a great
groove and for a song this slow there's
a lot of force to it there's a lot of
power to it it takes me back to Mogwai
albums like mr. beast the only major
letdown for me on this LP was the song
repeal --is-- a very moody instrumental
rock song with this vocal snippet of a
guy talking about subliminal satanic
messages in Led Zeppelin's Stairway to
Heaven which in concept sounds like a
very epic idea but when this guy talks
it feels like he's giving an oral report
in front of his classmates at some
Catholic school that he's enrolled in
overall I think rave tapes is a decent
release for Mogwai not quite as
underwhelming as the hawk is howling but
nowhere near one of my favorites of
theirs I admire what they're doing with
the sense and the electronics on this LP
but I do think some of the songwriting
is a little lackluster forgettable the
fact that a lot of the songs on this LP
are so reserved does sort of make it a
mood album and it's not like mood albums
don't already exist in mod wise
discography however for an LP that is so
driven by emotion I don't find it to be
particularly moving and that's all I'm
feeling a light a decent six on this
thing transition if you've given this LP
listen what did you think of it did you
love it
hate it why what do you think I should
review next and that's it
Anthony Fantana Mogwai forever
